Bill.Action: Pays Sam the Collector all the money he has and promises the rest next week, showing responsibility and honesty.
Threatens Sam by implying he knows people who can retaliate if harmed, showing intimidation rather than friendliness.
Negotiates with Sam the Collector's gang, asserts he has paid what he owes and hints at knowing people who can protect him.
Denies having done anything wrong despite the gang's suspicion, maintaining a confident stance.
Sobs with pain silently after Sam drops a keg of nails on his hand.
Lets go of the rope and runs when policemen ambush them, leaving Steve behind.
Picks up Steve's gun and fires back to protect him.
Weeps and expresses love for Steve as he is dying.
Lets go of the rope and starts to run when policemen ambush them, showing a survival instinct but abandoning the task.
Picks up Steve's gun and fires back at the policemen, attempting to defend himself and Steve.
Sobs with pain after Sam drops a keg of roofing nails on his hand, showing physical weakness or inability to endure pain silently.
Weeps and expresses emotional distress openly after Steve is shot and dies, showing emotional vulnerability but not necessarily competence in crisis.
Expresses love and appreciation to Abby, recalling happy moments together.
Cares for Abby when she is sick by feeding her hot soup.
Shows concern for Abby's safety by refusing to let her return to the dangerous mill.
Protects Abby by violently defending her against a policeman who roughs her up.
Shrugs off the violent confrontation and calmly collects laundry before fleeing.
Runs out and incapacitates a policeman by hitting him twice, including knocking him unconscious when the policeman reaches for a gun, then quickly escapes with Abby and Ursula.
Works in a mill but seems out of place and fallen on hard times, lacking a sense of belonging or clear skill in that environment.
Cares for Abby when she is sick by spooning hot soup into her mouth, showing attentiveness and responsibility.
Expresses hope and determination to improve their situation by planning to go west for a better life.
Shrugs after hitting the policeman the first time, showing a casual or indifferent attitude toward the danger they are in.
Shares a bottle of wine and laughs with Abby, expresses enjoyment of the sunshine and the open road, gestures out at the landscape with enthusiasm.
Draws Abby toward him despite her pulling away, makes a teasing comment about being irresistible.
Engages in lighthearted, confident banter with Abby, showing ease and self-assurance in social interaction.
Expresses a positive, optimistic view of their situation, recognizing opportunity in the open road and space.
Does not demonstrate any specific skill or problem-solving ability in the excerpt; mostly social and observational behavior.
Helps a big man covered in blood to his feet and dusts him off.
Struts around with a Napoleonic air, showing off his sword cane to set himself apart.
Dismisses Abby's concern about his injury with 'Nothing.'
Challenges the foreman Benson's wage offer skeptically.
Struts around confidently with a Napoleonic air, carrying a sword cane to set himself apart.

Confronts a tough man who then hits him on the head, and Bill walks off dizzily.
Dismisses Abby's concern about his injury with 'Nothing.'
Questions the foreman about wages and challenges the offer, causing the workers to have no choice but to accept.
Climbs up ahead of the women onto the wagon despite tension, showing assertiveness and control.

Looks deeply into Abby's eyes, shares a blood-mixing ritual, and expresses sincere affection.
Lifts a big rock, impressing Abby.
Engages in playful physical interaction with Abby, showing confidence and control.
Shouts at a bison, possibly showing bravado but lacking clear purpose or skill.
Joins Abby in reaping the wheat with a mowing machine called a binder, actively participating in the harvest work.
Works like a demon as a point of pride while others loaf when the overseer is not watching.
Dresses with flashy fashion and wears a white smock over it, giving an air more of a researcher than a worker.
Works like a demon when others loaf, showing strong work ethic and dedication.
Dresses flashy and more like a researcher than a worker, indicating possible focus on appearance over practical farming skills.
Has contempt for farming and those who practice it, suggesting a lack of respect or understanding for the work.
Throws a plate of stew at a man making a rude comment about Abby, then gets into a food fight to defend her.
Inspects Abby's swollen and cracked hands anxiously and presses her wrists against his cheek, ashamed he cannot protect her.
Scolds Abby for not taking care of herself and wearing gloves, expressing frustration but concern.
Tells Abby she is dragging him down and that it was a crime to bring her out here, expressing guilt and self-blame.
Throws a plate of stew at a loutish man and engages in a food fight, then storms away angrily.

Realistically assesses their situation and expresses determination to make enough for both of them.
Calls bringing Abby out here a crime and acknowledges his own failure, showing self-awareness but also defeat.
Suggests Abby should go back to Chicago and offers to send her money, showing concern for her well-being.

Comforts Abby when she cries, promising that things will improve.

Hunts nervously for medicine to soothe Abby's hands, showing concern for her well-being.

Says he can't get his mind on anything and just sleeps, indicating a lack of focus or motivation.
Rides back to the bonanza with his rabbit strapped to the motorcycle, stops to look at the new fields.
Appears behind Abby, who embraces him warmly but he feels hope leave him like a ghost, sensing distance and change.
Rides an Indian motorcycle along a muddy road back to the bonanza, carrying a rabbit strapped to the back, showing practical handling of transportation and responsibility.
Appears on the ridge behind Abby and senses her changed demeanor and distance, indicating awareness and perceptiveness.
Feels hope leave him like a ghost upon seeing Abby settled with Chuck, showing emotional vulnerability and possible lack of confidence in his situation.

Looks Abby up and down and comments on her dress and garden with genuine admiration, showing appreciation and attentiveness.

Expresses regret about not going into the church as his father wanted, showing some self-awareness but no direct action.

Expresses self-awareness and insight about their situation, admitting his mistakes and understanding Abby's position.

Seems surprised and unsure how to handle Abby's emotional collapse, indicating some lack of preparedness or emotional competence.

Looks for Chuck to speak with him before leaving again soon, showing awareness of timing and responsibility.

Swats at locusts with a shovel despite gagging and one flying into his mouth.
Takes Chuck by the shoulders and offers encouragement and sympathy during a moment of grief.
Takes a moment to observe the damage caused by locusts, showing awareness of the situation.

Grabs Chuck by the sleeve and tries to stop him from setting the fields on fire, showing awareness of the danger.

Slaps fire off his pantleg quickly when Chuck throws fire at him, showing alertness and quick reaction.
Backs off like a cat, sensing danger and confusion, showing caution but also uncertainty.
Turns and runs from Chuck when threatened, escaping successfully behind a wall of flame.
